sn18.1:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn18.1:4.3: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha,
sn18.1:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn18.1:4.6: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dharma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and determined.”
sn18.1:5.1: “What do you think, Rāhula? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn18.1:5.3: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn18.1:5.5: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn18.1:5.6: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn18.1:6.11: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn18.1:6.13: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn18.1:6.14: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn18.1:7.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with the eye,
sn18.1:7.9: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn18.1:7.10: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn18.1:7.11: (The ten discourses of this series should be treated in the same way.)
